Please follow existing file naming conventions.  All lowercase.

This is a really long file name.  Maybe it should be moved to a 'network' subdirectory?
Please add the proposed interfaces to phosphor-dbus-interfaces and link to it here.  I hate trying to review interfaces inside a design document.
Are we proposing any properties here?  If not, why do we need an empty interface?
Ack.Yes there are new properties needs to be added.I will submit the new dbus interface and property details in phosphor-dbus-interfaces repo.
I have updated the interface and respective property details in proper order.
What is the name of the interface?
Sorry Patrick, I didn't get what do you mean by "name of the interface"
The sentence talks about dbus objects being created, but I have no idea what dbus interfaces are going to be hosted at that path...
I have updated the proper interface details
Hi All, I have resolved the open review comments.If possible could you review the design once.
Filename is still really long and doesn't follow naming conventions.

NCSI?

I didn't request any change to the title.  I requested a change to the file name.

This paragraph is very confusing.  I think it is indicating the CLI utility usage and limitations, but the punctuation and language make it difficult to understand.  Can we reword this to better show the problem?
This should be referencing the 1.1.1 version of the spec and not 1.0.0.

This section should align with the NCSI spec.  In Section 6.2.13.2, step 3) indicates the commands necessary to obtain the capabilities for a given channel.  In 3. below, it should indicate it is following the NCSI spec section mentioned above for determining the capabilities of each channel.

updated the design document to capture the main requirement which is
to discover the available NCSI package and channels on the network controller.

This term is confusing as NCSI has a Get Capabilities command which returns specific data about the NIC.  Is this related to that command or something else?  The dbus objects mentioned below do not align with the response from that command as shown in the NCSI spec.
corrected the line. main purpose is to store available NCSI parameters such as package number and channel number.

This is confusing as the NCSI Get Capabilities response has two bit fields for HW Arbitration.  Bit Position 0 describes the HW Arbitration Capability and bit fields 6..5 indicate the HW Arbitration Implementation Status.  This property should be clearer to indicate which this is indicating.  

It would probably be easier to align the properties with the Capabilities Flags of the NCSI Get Capabilities response and not cherry-pick the bits.

I think we should add the other capabilities from the NCSI Get Capabilities response as well.  These include the Channel Count and whether the NIC provides VLAN Mode Support among others.  This Channel Count can be used to build the NCSI Channel Object path and corresponding data properties below as well.

updated the property details. as mentioned the main requirement pf the design is discovery of package and channel numbers which are available under the bmc network controller. this interface can be extended to store  additional capability info based on future requirement.
There is also an initial state where the channel is not in a ready/not ready state as indicated in the NCSI States indicated in Section 6.2.1 (Table 1) of the NCSI 1.1.1 spec.

Enabled/Disabled is defined as a sub-state of Ready.  It has no meaning if the channel is not ready.  Thus, if the channel is in a Not Ready state, this field should not be present as it will have any meaning.
It also needs some negative testing on a BMC platform which does not support NCSI to ensure it doesn't break anything.
Few minor text changes.  Overall, looks much better.
...the available devices and channels in the NIC...
Hi All, if possible could you help review the updated design regarding the NCSI discovery support under network manager?
Probably be good to give an example of _why_ you might need to know this before you jump into the nsci-netlink potential implementation.
nit: Please use 'D-Bus' or 'DBus' throughout.  It is not an acronym.
nit: This is a run-on sentence with commas in grammatically incorrect spots.
I don't understand this heading.  What is it an example of?  Can you just complete the earlier paragraph with this information?

How is phosphor-networkd going to actively monitor state changes?  It seems like earlier you implied it was going to call a separate command line utility instead of listening to the netlink socket itself, but I then don't understand how you detect state changes except through polling.
Right now the initial implementation is proposed to query the active NCSI package and channel info only one time at startup. So this info will not be actively monitored.
polls is probably a poor choice of words here, unless you really do mean actively polling?  Is there any other method other than polling?
Any performance impact due to polling?  Is this going to be handled as a separate thread inside networkd?  Or is there some hook to sd-event?
since the NCSI info is going to be queried only one time at startup of networkd service there will be no performance impact.
Hi all, could you help reviewing the latest patch for this design and shall we finalise this design if the latest design is fine?

We already have the NCSI application to get the package and channel info..What is not there is we don't publish it on to the D-bus.

As Patrick asked in the other comments why do we want to  have all this info on the D-bus.
space after comma and no capitalization

where is the design to inject PLDM messages via RBT?

The current ncsi stack only allows OEM userspace to inject oem packets

the selected state can change at any time.  why is this desirable?

the package id is fixed.

conversely the guid is defined at the package level and should remain fixed, so this would make sense along with the package id.

the active state can change at any time.

the link state can change at any time.

the kernel keeps track via AEN packets but doesn't signal userspace

I'd rather not have userspace trying to monitor the packets keeping track itself, so a signaling interface is not appropriate.    Maybe a get method if required, but how do we expect
not until you explain how it will be used
it's exposing stale information.   either its not needed or more justification
